text:
Even the simplest javadoc tasks result in a system freeze and/or blue screen. Other tasks 
including delete, mkdir, javac run without problems. "Execute javadoc" is the last status 
message before the failure.

<project name="test" default="javadoc" basedir=".">
  
<target name="javadoc">
    <javadoc
      destDir="./docs"
      
sourcefiles="FileCopy.java">
    </javadoc>
  </target>
</project>
creator: phil@codestyle.org
bodewig@apache.org
text: Does it happen when you use <property environment="env"/> as well (no javadoc)?

creator: phil@codestyle.org
text:
Yes, this build crashes Windows ME with a simple environment property, the status is "environment:" with nothing following and the system locks, e.g.

<project name="test" default="environment" basedir=".">
  <target name="environment">
    <property environment="env"/>
  </target>
</project>

OK, so it happens every time an external command gets called.

I must admit that I've never seen (or even used) a box running Windows ME.
Does it use command.com (like Win9x) or cmd.exe (like Windows NT) as command
line shell?  As far as Ant is concerned, Windows ME is Win9x.
creator: bodewig@apache.org
phil@codestyle.org
text:
Yes, that's ME for malignant edition ;-

COMSPEC=C:\WINDOWS\COMMAND.COM

ME seems to run command 
line applications in a wrapper called "WinOldApp" or "OLDAPP".

If there are any other 
diagnostics you require, please let me know, I'd be happy to help out.

I'm not Windows expert at all, hopefully some other fellow Ant committer can jump
in here.

First of all, let me check that my assumptions are correct, could you please
provide the output of the following snippet:

<project default="check">
  <target name="check">
    <echo message="${os.name}"/>
    <condition property="win">
      <os family="windows"/>
    </condition>
    <echo message="${win}"/>
    <condition property="win9x">
      <os family="win9x"/>
    </condition>
    <echo message="${win9x}"/>
  </target>
</project>

Next, what happens if you type

command.com /c set

in a DOS box?
